text:
Each year at Commencement,
we honor a handful

of distinguished HBS alumni
who are, in every way,

role models for how we
hope our graduates will
lead their lives.

Let me introduce our 2022 Alumni
Achievement Award recipients.

I am delighted to present the
five remarkable women and men,

who through their actions
and their behaviors

and in their careers and
in their communities,

are exceptionally worthy
recipients of this,
the school's highest honor.

For each recipient, I will read
a short biographical sketch.

Those of you on stage
can remain seated.

I will then present you with
a citation asking those of you

on stage to join
me at the podium.

Patricia "Tosh"
Barron, MBA 1972.

Tosh Barron's father
would have preferred
her to be more academic.

But in Barron's words,
that was a long shot.

She grew up playing
every sport imaginable
and trained as a modern dancer.

When some Rhodes scholars
living near her in Oxford

told her to try living
in America, she did.

Tosh thought she might want
to manage an arts organization

and applied to HBS,
an experience that
changed her life forever.

On assignment for
McKinsey and in Tanzania,

she became good
friends with a woman,

who when diagnosed
with terminal cancer,

asked Tosh to
adopt her two sons.
She did.

Rising through the ranks
of Xerox Corporation,

she led the company's entry
into the Chinese market,

ultimately serving as president
of its $8 billion office
products division.

At a time when few women
had a seat at the table,

she was lead director on
multiple corporate boards,

choosing her words
with integrity

and speaking in a clear
voice to make them heard.

An active listener,
doer, and thinker, Tosh

may not have been the
student her father hoped for,

yet her personal life
and career demonstrate

what can happen when we
say yes to the unexpected.
Tosh, please join me.

I'm going to read a
citation now for you.
[APPLAUSE]
This is too much.
[BOTH CHUCKLE]
[INAUDIBLE]
Yeah.
Yes.

Brave Brit, you
crossed the ocean

to forge a new path
in a new country,

dancing and pivoting from
the stage to the highest
levels of business leadership.

An open listener and eager
learner, your integrity

and energy have left
an imprint on everyone

you've touched, from the
family room to the boardroom.

Whether opening a new market
in China, guiding governance

with a steady hand, or
walking in Central Park,

the joy you find in
the world around you

reminds us all to keep
raising our sights.
Thank you so much, honestly.
[APPLAUSE]

Our next award recipient
is Salman Khan,
and he is going to be remote.

It's a story that has
been told a few times
but bears repeating.

In 2004, when Sal Khan was
working as a hedge fund

analyst, he started tutoring
his 12-year-old cousin in math.

That impulse to help one
person planted the seed
for Khan Academy.

Today, more than 135 million
people in 190 countries

turn to the free site
to learn math, science,
and the humanities.

Raised by a single
mother, product

of Louisiana's
public school system,

Sal believes passionately
that all students should

be allowed to move
at their own pace

and master the
material being taught.

That conviction has
sparked a revolution

in classrooms around the
world with parents, teachers,

and districts coming
to see Khan Academy

as a pioneering partner, a
relationship that not only grew

in importance when
the pandemic shut down
schools across the globe.

An entrepreneur in
every sense of the word,

Sal leads a dynamic
organization that

continues to evolve, pivot,
and grow in its reach,

meeting universal demand for
a vitally important product--
knowledge.

The word visionary is
sometimes overused.

In Sal's case, it
undoubtedly applies.
I'll now read Sal's citation.

Education entrepreneur,
your love of learning

constructed a classroom
open to millions.

Authentic and unassuming, your
optimism, vision, and humor

encode the DNA of everything you
create from calculus problems
to global partnerships.

Dedicated father and
down-to-earth leader,

far-sighted and
clear-eyed, your delight

in discovery and
commitment to mastery

bring light to all
corners of the Earth.
[APPLAUSE]

Our next recipient is here
in person, Naina Lal Kidwai.

When Naina Kidwai was a girl,
she visited her father's office

and spun around in
his big leather chair,

dreaming of a
future in business.

After college, she applied to
work at an accounting firm.
There was just one problem.
They didn't hire women.
Naina didn't let that deter her.

The first woman from India to
graduate from Harvard Business
School, she went home.
[CHEERS, APPLAUSE]

She went home and
quickly began making

a difference, both
to her country

and to the many financial
institutions where

she led change and growth,
from Grindlays Bank to Morgan
Stanley to HSBC.

Whether helping establish
a second stock exchange,

guiding the public listing
of global Indian companies,

overseeing the safe
return of employees

during a deadly
terrorist attack,

or piloting early efforts to
create an inclusive workplace,

Naina approached her work
with authenticity, heart,
and a strong sense of duty.

That commitment continues today
with her founding of the India

Sanitation Coalition, a
multi-sector collaboration

to end open defecation
and improve water quality.

Naina, thank you for dreaming
big from the beginning

and for lighting the way
so others could follow.
[APPLAUSE]

Daughter of Delhi, with
talent and determination,

you drive global change
benefiting women everywhere.

Investing in your
country's future,

you came home to energize
India's financial sector,

rising to lead at
HSBC while fostering
diversity and inclusion.

Compassionate nature lover, you
continue to make a difference,

improving the environment,
the health, and the lives
of your fellow citizens.
[APPLAUSE]

Robert Ryan, MBA 1970,
whom you heard yesterday
in the Class Day festivities--

Bob Ryan's father had a job
working at a Chrysler plant
in Detroit, Michigan.

He told his son he also had a
job getting good citizenship

grades, good academic
grades, and helping
around the house, no excuses.

Bob heard that message
loud and clear.

Excelling at school, he answered
his country's space race

call for engineers and enrolled
in the PhD program at Cornell.

Well on his way to a
secure successful future,
he realized he was on autopilot.

Following his love
of business, he

applied to Harvard
Business School

and financed his MBA by
selling the new Pontiac
he had worked so hard to buy.

At McKinsey, Citibank,
and Union Texas Petroleum,

Bob leaned into every
challenge and contributed

to a period of tremendous
innovation and growth

while serving as
CFO of Medtronic.

Realizing the role education
played in his life,

he mentors others and
makes giving back a given.

Recently, that principal
found an unexpected outlet

when he used his
financial expertise

to save a funeral home
in Minneapolis that

has served the African-American
community for over 50 years.

By caring deeply and
executing with excellence,

Bob changes the landscape
and the lives of everyone
around him.
[APPLAUSE]

Devoted son of Detroit, you took
your parents' values to heart

but found a different direction
pursuing your fascination
with finance.

Confronted by
volatility, you dug deep,

staying the course at Union
Texas before masterfully moving
Medtronic in new markets.

With careful consideration
and a generous spirit,

you give with grace,
magnifying opportunity and hope

from the north side of
Minneapolis and beyond.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]

And our last awardee is Robert
Wilson, MBA 1961, DBA 1963,
and Bob is going to be remote.

Bob Wilson came to Harvard
College from Lincoln, Nebraska

on a General Motors
national scholarship.

Cambridge was a bit
of a culture shock,

and he struggled to find
meaning in his studies.

Luckily, he met Howard
Raiffa, a professor
who was moving over to HBS.
Bob followed him.

Chagrined that his elegant
mathematical equations weren't

appreciated in a more
managerial context,

Bob persevered,
hitting his stride

in the doctoral
program then driving

to California with
his young family

to begin decades
of extraordinarily
productive scholarship.

Encouraging and exacting in his
guidance of graduate students,

he suggested they
work on problems
that matter to the world.

Taking his own advice, he
collaborated with a colleague

to design more efficient
ways of auctioning everything

from cell phone frequencies
to mineral and timber rights.

That work has generated
an estimated $1.5 trillion

in revenues, a staggering
savings for governments
and taxpayers around the world.

Bob won the Nobel Prize in
economics two years ago.

His own brand of
down-to-earth brilliance

will continue to shine
well into the future

in newfound applications
of his research.
[APPLAUSE]
I'll now read Bob's citation.
It reads as follows.

Plainspoken Nebraska native,
your brilliance and curiosity

took you from
Harvard to Stanford

to the global
stage in Stockholm.

Holding a new lens
to an old problem,

you transformed how the
world approaches auctions,

increasing transparency
and improving outcomes
to make everyone a winner.

Humble and big-hearted,
your meaningful mentorship

shows how one person's
encouragement can ignite ideas

across generations, sparking new
discoveries that enrich us all.
[APPLAUSE]

Let's have a final round of
applause for all our Alumni
Achievement Award recipients.

You truly exemplify the school's
mission and make a difference.
[APPLAUSE]
